Apple___Apple_scab.description: Apple scab is a common fungal disease affecting apple and crabapple trees, caused by Venturia inaequalis. It begins with olive-brown velvety spots on young leaves and fruit in spring, expanding into corky lesions. Severe infections lead to early defoliation and misshapen, unmarketable fruit.
symptoms: Olive‑green to brown velvety spots on leaves
Apple___Apple_scab.impact: Reduces photosynthesis, weakens trees, decreases fruit yield and quality over time.
prevention_control: Collect and destroy fallen leaves to remove overwintering spores
Prune for air circulation and sunlight penetration
Apply fungicides at green tip, pink bud, and post-bloom stages
Grow resistant cultivars where possible

Apple___Black_rot.description: Black rot is a severe fungal disease caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa. It starts with small purple spots on leaves that enlarge into brown concentric-ring lesions. Fruit develop black, sunken spots that rot and mummify, often showing a distinctive “frog-eye” pattern. Twigs may develop cankers under high disease pressure.
Apple___Black_rot.impact: Significantly reduces fruit yield and marketability; persists in mummified fruit and dead wood to re-infect annually.
prevention_control: Prune and burn infected branches and twigs
Remove fallen and mummified fruit from orchard floor
Apply protectant and post-infection fungicides during humid seasons
Maintain tree health and air circulation to reduce infection sites

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: Cedar-apple rust is a fungal disease requiring two hosts—junipers and apples/crabapples—to complete its life cycle :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}. It causes bright yellow-orange spots on apple leaves and fruit after spring infection, followed by orange gelatinous spore horns emerging from leaf undersides in wet conditions :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
symptoms: Yellow to orange spots on leaf uppersides
Black dots or aecia on undersides beneath spots
Orange, gelatinous telial horns from galls on juniper hosts
Raised spots or cracking on apple fruit
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.impact: Causes early defoliation when extensive, weakens trees and reduces fruit quality; juniper trees develop unsightly galls :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.
prevention_control: Remove nearby juniper/cedar within 1–4 miles to interrupt spore cycle
Prune and destroy galls on junipers before spring rains
Apply fungicides (e.g., captan, thiophanate-methyl) from apple green tip through petal fall :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Use resistant apple/crabapple cultivars when available

Apple___healthy.description: Healthy apple leaf or fruit—no disease detected.

Blueberry___healthy.description: Healthy blueberry leaf or fruit—no disease detected.

Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.description: Powdery mildew on cherry manifests as white, powdery fungal growth on the surface of leaves, blossoms, and fruit. It can distort young leaves, stunt growth, reduce photosynthesis, and lower yield.
symptoms: White, floury patches on leaves and shoots
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.impact: Weakens tree health, diminishes yield and fruit quality, and predisposes to other diseases.
prevention_control: Improve air circulation through pruning
Remove infected shoots and leaves
Apply sulfur or potassium bicarbonate-based fungicides at first signs
Plant resistant cherry varieties

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.description: Healthy cherry leaf or fruit—no disease detected.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: Cercospora leaf spot (gray leaf spot) in corn starts as small, tan specks on leaves, expanding into rectangular gray-brown lesions with dark margins aligned between veins. Under humid conditions, spores spread rapidly, causing defoliation and impaired grain fill.
symptoms: Rectangular tan-brown lesions with dark borders
Leaf senescence beginning at the tips
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.impact: Premature leaf death can reduce yield by limiting photosynthesis and grain development.
prevention_control: Plant resistant hybrids and rotate crops
Apply foliar fungicides (e.g., azoxystrobin) at VT–R1 stage
Manage residue to reduce inoculum
Avoid excessive irrigation late in season

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.description: Common rust of corn, caused by Puccinia sorghi, features reddish-brown pustules on both leaf surfaces. Under favorable conditions, pustules erupt and release spores, which spread rapidly through crops.
symptoms: Reddish-brown pustules on leaves and husks
Pustules may merge in severe cases
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.impact: Reduces photosynthetic leaf area, can lower yield if infection occurs early or hot humid weather persists.
prevention_control: Plant resistant hybrids where available
Use protective fungicides if early-season infection occurs
Destroy volunteer corn plants to reduce spore sources

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Northern corn leaf blight appears as long, elliptical gray-green lesions that expand rapidly, often merging across leaf blades. Severe blight leads to extensive leaf death and can stunt plants if infection occurs early.
symptoms: Lesions on husks and stalks in heavy infection
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.impact: Can significantly reduce yield, especially if plants are infected before tasseling.
prevention_control: Use resistant varieties
Rotate crops and till residue
Apply fungicides when lesions first appear
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization

Grape___Black_rot.description: Grape black rot is a destructive fungal disease caused by Guignardia bidwellii, favored by warm, humid weather :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}. Symptoms start with small yellow spots on leaves that become tan centers with dark red-brown borders and black pycnidia. As spores spread, lesions form on shoots, tendrils, and fruit; berries rot, shrivel into mummies covered with black pycnidia :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.
symptoms: Small circular to irregular tan lesions on leaves with dark margins
Black pycnidia (fruiting bodies) in concentric rings
Black sunken lesions on shoots, tendrils, rachis
Grape___Black_rot.impact: Can cause severe crop losses—early cluster infection leads to fruit death; mummies overwinter and serve as inoculum; defoliation may occur in recurrent infection years :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.
prevention_control: Sanitize by removing mummies and infected canes during dormant pruning
Apply multi-season protectant and post-infection fungicides :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
Promote airflow through canopy management
Plant resistant varieties where feasible

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).description: Esca, also called black measles in grapes, is a complex trunk and vascular disease caused by multiple fungi. It causes interveinal “tiger stripe” foliar symptoms late in season and dark, sunken lesions on fruit resembling black spots.
symptoms: White rot in wood, with fruity odor
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).impact: Chronic vine health decline, yield reduction, and vine loss; internal wood rot weakens structural integrity.
prevention_control: Prune out and destroy dead wood and infected arms
Sanitize pruning tools between cuts
Apply delayed-dormant fungicides (e.g., sodium arsenite where allowed)
Promote vine vigor and avoid wounding

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.description: Grape leaf blight (Isariopsis) shows up as chlorotic spots on leaves that become tan-to-brown with dark margins. Under humid conditions, lesions may coalesce, causing premature leaf drop and reduced fruit quality.
symptoms: Yellow to chlorotic round spots on leaves
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.impact: Reduces vine vigor by defoliation, decreases fruit quality and sugar accumulation.
prevention_control: Apply protectant fungicides (e.g., chlorothalonil) early season
Remove infected leaves
Improve canopy ventilation
Avoid overhead watering

Grape___healthy.description: Healthy grape leaf or fruit—no disease detected.

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).description: Huanglongbing (citrus greening) is a destructive bacterial disease spread by psyllid vectors. Infected trees show mottled leaves, yellow shoots, small crooked fruit with aborted seeds, and eventual decline :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).impact: Causes yield loss, fruit drop, and eventual tree death; no cure exists; severe economic consequences for citrus producers.
prevention_control: Remove and destroy infected trees
Control psyllid vectors using insecticides
Plant disease-free nursery stock
Use protective tree netting where feasible

Peach___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot of peach results in small, water-soaked spots on leaves and fruit that enlarge and turn dark brown with scabby appearances. Infected leaves may drop, and fruit can crack, lowering marketability.
symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit
Dark, scabby sunken spots on fruit
Peach___Bacterial_spot.impact: Reduces yield and fruit quality, promotes secondary infections, and weakens tree vigor over time.
prevention_control: Apply copper-based sprays during bloom and early season
Prune for air circulation
Avoid overhead irrigation
Plant less susceptible peach cultivars

Peach___healthy.description: Healthy peach leaf or fruit—no disease detected.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot on bell pepper causes greasy, dark lesions on leaves and fruit, which may merge and crack, leading to unmarketable produce.
symptoms: Greasy, dark brown spots on leaves
Raised lesions on fruit, often cracking
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.impact: Decreases yield and quality, limits sale of produce, and can remain in crop residue to infect next season.
prevention_control: Use certified disease-free seed and transplants
Apply copper bactericides regularly
Remove infected plants/plant material
Practice crop rotation and sanitation

Pepper,_bell___healthy.description: Healthy bell pepper leaf or fruit—no disease detected.

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight of potato, caused by Alternaria solani, produces target-shaped brown lesions with concentric rings on older leaves, fingertips, stems, and tubers. Under warm, humid conditions, lesions spread quickly, leading to significant plant stress.
symptoms: Tan-to-brown target spots on foliage with concentric rings
Lesions on stems may girdle and kill shoots
Black scabby patches on tuber surfaces
Potato___Early_blight.impact: Lowers yield and tuber quality significantly when infection is severe; promotes premature vine death.
prevention_control: Apply protectant fungicides (e.g., chlorothalonil, mancozeb) when disease first appears
Rotate with non-host crops
Remove volunteer potatoes
Avoid overhead irrigation
